critique: This document is a short executive order that waives civil service rules to allow two specific individuals to be appointed to classified positions in the Department of Labor. It is difficult to assess the ideological tilt without more context, but given it is from 1933, it likely aligns with the New Deal era. There is no mention of immigration, executive power, federalism, national security, economic regulation, or social inclusion in the document. Therefore, most axes will be scored as neutral. The exception is economic regulation, which could be seen as a slight intervention, and social inclusion, which could be seen as slightly favoring conformity since it is about specific individuals rather than broader policies.
